jparsec.math

Class FastMath

  • java.lang.Object
    • jparsec.math.FastMath

  • public class FastMath
extends java.lang.Object
    Provides methods for fast (approximate) calculation of trigonometric functions. Memory consumption is low, about 7 kB per trigonometric table, and speed is several times better. Some methods comes from the FastMath library by Bill Rossi, integrated in Apache Commons Math.
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    T. Alonso Albi - OAN (Spain)

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static boolean ACCURATE_MODE
      Sets the accurate mode flag for sin/cos/atan2 functions.
      static boolean EXACT_MODE
      Set to true to use exact mode, with no speed optimization.

    • Field Detail

      • ACCURATE_MODE

        public static boolean ACCURATE_MODE
        Sets the accurate mode flag for sin/cos/atan2 functions. Default is true and will produce errors of 4E-7 for sin/cos and 8E-5 for the accurate version of the atan2 function. In case you set it to false you should increase the number of angles by a factor 10 at least for an acceptable (and just 10% faster) sin/cos.

      • EXACT_MODE

        public static boolean EXACT_MODE
        Set to true to use exact mode, with no speed optimization. Default is false.

    • Method Detail

      • initialize

        public static void initialize()
        Initializes the cache for sin and cos and the rest.

      • setMaximumNumberOfAngles

        public static void setMaximumNumberOfAngles(int n)
        Sets the maximum number of angles to calculate. Default value is 3600, producing errors in the sin/cos values of around 4E-7 if ACCURATE_MODE is true. The initialization of the variables sin and cos is also done when calling this method.
        Parameters:
        n - The number of angles.

      • getMaximumNumberOfAngles

        public static int getMaximumNumberOfAngles()
        Returns the maximum number of angles.
        Returns:
        Maximum number of angles.

      • getResolution

        public static double getResolution()
        Returns the resolution of the calculations, defined as the number of calculation angles divided by 2 PI.
        Returns:
        The resolution.

      • sincos

        public static void sincos(double x,
          boolean fast,
          double[] sincos)
        Computes the sine and cosine of the argument in one call.
        Parameters:
        x - The argument.
        fast - True to force disabling the accurate mode for better performance. In other functions this is set to false.
        sincos - A previously allocated array of at least 2 elements to hold the sine and cosine.

      • tan

        public static double tan(double x)
        Calculates the tangent of the argument. For critical arguments around PI/2 or 3PI/2 the maximum relative error is below 1%. This function is around 8 times faster than intrinsic Java function.
        Parameters:
        x - Argument.
        Returns:
        Its tangent.

      • asin

        public static double asin(double x)
        Calculates the arc-sine of the argument. Accuracy similar or better compared to sin and cos functions except for arguments very close to 1 or -1, where errors up to 0.1º can be reached. 33x faster than intrinsic.
        Parameters:
        x - Argument.
        Returns:
        Its arc-sine.

      • acos

        public static double acos(double x)
        Calculates the arc-cosine of the argument. Accuracy similar or better compared to sin and cos functions except for arguments very close to 1 or -1, where errors up to 0.1º can be reached. 33x faster than intrinsic.
        Parameters:
        x - Argument.
        Returns:
        Its arc-cosine.

      • atan2

        public static double atan2(double y,
           double x)
        Performs fast approximate atan2 calculation, with a maximum error of 0.005 radians or 0.3 degrees. If used for rotating coordinates in a 1000 px screen resolution, maximum error will be 2 px. It is 10 times faster than Math.atan2. Based on Hastings approximations. Note certain critical angles cannot be obtained with this method, so it is not suitable to obtain spherical coordinates.

        For angles between +/- 45 deg this function uses atan(double), with an accuracy 3 times better and only slightly worse performance.

        Parameters:
        y - Y value.
        x - X value.
        Returns:
        The atan2.

      • atan2_accurate

        public static double atan2_accurate(double y,
                    double x)
        Performs fast atan2 approximation using cordic, more accurate than the other function, but not so fast. Its error is 2.5E-4 radians (0.015 deg), about 20 times more accurate than Hastings approximation, but 60% slower. It has an excellent ratio performance/accuracy. Suitable to be used in spherical coordinates. Function created by Simon Hosie, see http://www.dsprelated.com/showmessage/10922/1.php.

        In case ACCURATE_MODE is true more terms will be used, with a precision up to 8E-5 radians (0.005 deg), but calculations will be slightly slower. This mode is still 4.5 times faster than intrinsic Math.atan2.

        Parameters:
        y - Y value.
        x - X value.
        Returns:
        The arctan.

      • sign

        public static int sign(double n)
        Returns the sign of the argument.
        Parameters:
        n - A value.
        Returns:
        0 if value = 0, 1 if value > 0, -1 if value < 0.

      • atan

        public static double atan(double x)
        Returns the approximate arctan of the argument. Maximum error is 0.09 deg. 20 times faster than intrinsic function. For x outside -1 to 1 the intrinsic function is called.
        Parameters:
        x - The tangent.
        Returns:
        The arctan.

      • exp_approx

        public static double exp_approx(double val)
        Performs fast approximate exponential function, with a maximum error of 4%, and usually around 2%. 10 times faster than intrinsic function, and 3 times faster than exp(double).
        Parameters:
        val - The argument.
        Returns:
        The exponential.

        Natural logarithm. Math.log is called.
        Parameters:

        Returns:

        public static double expm1(double x)
        Compute exp(x) - 1
        Parameters:
        x - number to compute shifted exponential
        Returns:
        exp(x) - 1

      • exp

        public static double exp(double val)
        Exponential function. Just slightly faster than intrinsic exp. Computes exp(x), function result is nearly rounded. It will be correctly rounded to the theoretical value for 99.9% of input values, otherwise it will have a 1 UPL error. Method: Lookup intVal = exp(int(x)) Lookup fracVal = exp(int(x-int(x) / 1024.0) * 1024.0 ); Compute z as the exponential of the remaining bits by a polynomial minus one exp(x) = intVal * fracVal * (1 + z) Accuracy: Calculation is done with 63 bits of precision, so result should be correctly rounded for 99.9% of input values, with less than 1 ULP error otherwise.
        Parameters:
        val - a double
        Returns:
        double ex

      • pow

        public static double pow(double x,
         double y)
        Performs fast pow function. When y is integer and below +/- 6 output is exact and 6 times faster than Math.pow. When y is integer and x = 10 the function multiplyBy10ToTheX(double, int) is called, otherwise Math.pow is called.
        Parameters:
        x - Base.
        y - Exponent.
        Returns:
        x^y.

        Returns:
        hyperbolic cosine of x

      • sqrt

        public static double sqrt(double a)
        Performs fast approximate sqrt function. It is 50% faster than intrinsic function, and the error is 4% or below for arguments below 10000.
        Parameters:
        a - The argument.
        Returns:
        sqrt(a).

      • getExponent

        public static int getExponent(double d)
        Return the exponent of a double number, removing the bias.

        For double numbers of the form 2x, the unbiased exponent is exactly x.

        Parameters:
        d - number from which exponent is requested
        Returns:
        exponent for d in IEEE754 representation, without bias

      • getExponent

        public static int getExponent(float f)
        Return the exponent of a float number, removing the bias.

        For float numbers of the form 2x, the unbiased exponent is exactly x.

        Parameters:
        f - number from which exponent is requested
        Returns:
        exponent for d in IEEE754 representation, without bias
